div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, Tuesday, APRIL 4, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.

Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: JAPS ADVANCE ON KIBIN
div.p: The Japanese have occupied Mienhauchin,
which is on .the Ivirin road, 16 miles to the
northeast- of Kaiyuan.

div.head: RIGOROUS REPRESSION IN RUSSIA CONFLICT WITH SOCIALISTS
div.p: A serious conflict has taken place here be-
tween a crowd, composed of 1,000 Socialists,
mostly Jews'with red flags, and a mixed patrol
of military and police consisting of 20 men.
The police declare that the Socialists fired
upon them with their revolvers, whereupon the
former poured several volleys into the crowd.
killing four and wounding 40. Many arrests
were made.

div.head: RUSSIAN EFFORTS AT CONCILIATION.
div.p: St. Petersburg, April 3.
Marked efforts are being made to conciliate
Finland. The obnoxious military law, imposed
in 1901, has been virtually abrogated, and the
dismissal of the judges, who refused to enforce
it, is rescinded.

div.head: THE SULTAN AND FRANCE.
div.p: Tangier, April 3.

The curtailing ol the Kaiser’s visit here is now explained by a statement to the effect that the Emperor received on board a message from the Sultan virtually bailing him as a protector against France. The Kaiser, declining to endorse such sentiments, refused to land. The German Minister ultimately persuaded him to charge his mind, otherwise German prestige would have suffered considerably. The Kaiser went- direct to the German Legation, and did not enter the Moorish Palace, which had been specially prepared for him. The upshot of it all is that the Moors and French are alike offended.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Foot and Mouth Disease has broken out in Cairo. ; All Saints’.—Bishop Morley will hold a confirmation to-morrpw at All Saints’ Church, Cairo, at 10.30 a.m. S.P.C.A.—Mrs. Mosely has given a dona- tion of £20 to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at Cairo. Lunatic Asylum.—Mr. P. Keith has been appointed molahiz of the Lunatic Asylum at Abbassieh, as from January 1, 1905. Mrs. P. Keith has been appointed matron from the same date. Greek Plays at Alexandria.—The Theatre Royal company from Athens is jto give eleven performances at Alexandria, and will open shortly at the Zizinia Theatre with the Plutus of Aristophanes. Stray and Ownerless Dog found in Old Cairo on the night of Wednesday, and morning of Thursday, and in the Bab Sharia district on the night of Thursday and morning of Friday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE
div.p: Referring to our. remarks in yesterday’s issue
with reference to the new site chosen for
Victoria College, we now learn that the com-
mittee has concluded au exceptionally favor-
able arrangement with Mr. Perioles Glymeno-
poulo, who not only has ceded to them a
superficies of about 130,00Q pics of land at
Ramleh fronting the Khedivial Palace, at the
very reasonable price of P.T. 15 per pio, but
has also made the very generous offer to lend
the committee of the Victoria College a sum
of £15,000 for the spuse of three years at 5%
interest in order to enable them to commence
the~work of building the new oollege at once,
which would not have been possible blit for
this offer, as we understand that the com-
mittee were not in a position to commence the
building until such' time as they had been
able to dispose of the land on which the present
college stands. There is now no necessity for
any hurry in disposing of same.
Needless to say, the munificent offer of Mr.
Glymenoponlo has been accepted by the com-
mittee, and we certainly think that the thanks
of the entire British community are due to
this geutlemeu for the great interest, and
disinterestedness he has shown in the matter.

div.head: ENGLISH EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: The remarks we' made in onr issue of Friday
last in our analysis of England’s imports to
Egypt, as disclosed by the returns of the
Customs Administration for the past year, are
re-echoed in the following paragraph from the
“Review of Reviews” for March
One of the most popular excuses for war is
that it is necessary to out throats to secure
markets. Apart from the morality.
of this doctrine, our experience in Egypt
seems to prove that although we spent millions
in securing a. predominant position in the
Valley of the Nile, it is Germany, which never
spent a penny or killed a man, that reaped
the increase of trade. Twenty years ago
57.7 per cent, of the imports into Egypt came
from Great Britain, last year onr proportion
had fallen to 34 per cent. Twenty years ago
Germany only exported 0.4 per cent, of the
total imports info Egypt; last year she ex-
ported 4 per cent., a teufold increase in twenty
years. We lost 3.7 per cent, of the import
trade; Germany gained 3.6. Whatever else
these figures prove, they do not exactly
encourage the idea that fighting for markets
is a profitable investment of capital.
momingj alter Having been tied op for nearly
The Eastern Telegraph Suez Canal wires
were temporarily repaired at 6 a.m. to-day and
direct communication was restored.

div.head: INDUSTRIAL AND FINANCE CORPORATION
div.p: Mr. Justice Kekewich, .inthe Cbancgry Divi- sion on March 27, commenced the hearing of an action by Dr. Robert William Felkin against the Palmerston Industrial and Finance Corpora- tion, Ltd., and Mr. Alfred Bridge, of 15, Cockspnr-street, S.W., claiming rescission of an agreement to take 800 shares in the Sudan Exploration, Ltd., and a declaration that defendants were liable to indemnify plaintiff in respect to all expenses incurred by him in relation to the trasaotion. In the alternative, plaintiff asked for damages for misrepresenta- tion.—Mr. P. Ogden Lawrence, K.C., and Mr. J.H. Simmons appeared Tor the plaintiff; Mr. Ashton Cross for the Palmerston Corporation; and Mr. W.J.L Ambrose for Mr. Bridge. Mr. Lawrence said Dr. Felkin had spent some time in Egypt, and knew the Sudan well. When he returned to England, unfortun- ately for himself, he got mixed up with the defendant Bridge, who w*s.a company promoter, le was first attracted to Bridge by an adver- tisement in a London pspet for a gentleman to act as director of a public company, and willing to subscribe £1,000. Bridge's exact relationship to the Palmerston Corporation counsel said he did not know; but he appeared to have drawn cheques in the name of the corporation and in the name of the directors. Generally he appear- ed tb he the company himself. Bridge first got ! )r. Felkin interested in the Palmerston Corporation, and then, finding that the plaintiff mew a great dial about Sudan cotton-plant- ing and transport, he brought to his notice the Sudan Exploration Cdmpany. Bridge told plaintiff that if he would take 800 £1 shares le should have them' for £1,000, and that he would accept, on behalf of the Palmerston Corporation, a bill accepted by Dr. Felkin at three months. Bridge also said that he wonld be able to sell for plaintiff enough of the shares which he controlled, so as to give plaintiff cash to pay for them-1 that was to say, that they were shares which would go up on the market Plaintiff was to retain the balance of the shares left Counsel said he thought he would be able to show that the corporation did not control the shares. Subse- quently Dr. Felkin attended at Bridge’s, office, and accepted a bill drawn by Bridge. The bill was endorsed by Dr. Bryant The bill found its way into the hands of a moneylender named Lsvene, having been discounted by Bridge, who received a cheque for £800. Plain- tiff had not been ablS to ascertain what became of the £800, and whether it went into the Palmerston Company's coffers, or into Bridge’s hands. When the bill matured Bridge gave the money lenders two other bills, the pre- mium for renewal being £125. Plaintiff went to Bridge’s offioe and accepted the bills, whioh were again endorsed by Dr. Bryant. The plaintiff was unable to find the money to meet the bills, and-there was no sale of the shares, which plaintiff believed were never in the pos- session or nnder the control of the Palmerston Corporation at all. The money lender brought an notion against the drawer, the endorser and the acceptor of the bills, and judgment was obtained against both drawer and endorser. Mr. Ambrose, interposing, said that judg-' merit was against Bridge, but not by oonsent. Proceeding, Mr. Lawrence said plaintiff settled the action by paying the moneylender, as he was advised that whatever remedy he bad was in the present aotion. Counsel contend- ed that plaintiff never had any consideration, and that be never saw the shares, and he did not believe that the defendant corporation ever controlled them. He believed that the £800 was got out of him by Bridge for his own person- al benefit. The corporation had put in a defenoe stating that it was always willing and ready to hand over the shares to the plaintiff, and it denied that the policy and business of the corporation were controlled by Bridge, nor did it admit that such representations were made by Bridge as alleged by the plaintiffs. The defendant Bridge had pleaded that if he did make any statement or representations concerning the present or future value of the shares in the Sudan Exploration Company, they were boua fide expressions of opinion. The plaintiff, Dr. Felkin, was called, and was under examination when the Court adjourned.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: At the last meeting of the oomm ittee of the
Helouan Sporting Club, held in Cairo at the
Palace of H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly, the hon
secretary laid before the oommittee the profit-
and loss account and balance sheet of the
club for the season 1901-1905, whioh was con-
sidered most satisfactory from every point of
view. No less than L E. 760 were given away
Mr. RAN. Johnson, of the firm of De Rooe,
Johnson and Co., of London, has arrived in
Egypt and is staying et the Grand Continental
Hotel, Cairo,
Notwithstanding that we are nearing the
fag-end of the season the small dtipa
Shepheard’s last night mu a great snooess.
Dancing was kept up very animatedly until one
o’clock this morning) when several suppAr
parties took place in the grill-ream. As usual,
the restaurant at dinner-time was crowded.
Among those there we notioed R R. H.
George William, Duke of Brunswiok-Lunebaigi
and suite, including Baron Vereele and
Dr.' Lurtz, Sir Thomas and Lady Murray,
Mr. andMre. SebUne and Thurneyssen Pasha,
Baron Drasohe and party of 7,- inwlmling
Count Michiel and Sir Ross Hume,Col. Watson
and 6 guests, Capt. Kennedy and party of 5,
Baron and Baroness von Alton, (fount Tys-
kiewicz, Mr. von Alaen, Capt Bruninghaus,
Mr. and Mrs. Em. Zervudaohi, Mr. and Mrs.
H. Bacon and party, Mr. and Mrs. G. Festa,
Mrs. Mather and the Misses Kerby, Mrs.
Attwood-Matthews and three guests, includ-
ing Mrs. and Miss Moore and Major Lawron

div.head: Egyptian land and general trust
div.p: CAPITAL......................... £200,000, Divided into £200,000 Shares of £1 each. With power to increase to £500,000 upon Resolution of the Board. Are now issuing a prospectus -by which the Directoirs invite Subscriptions i at par for £200,000 Shares. PAYMENTS MOST BE MADE AS FOLLOWS—2/- on Application, and 3/- on Allotment And the when required, in Calls of 5/- each, at intervals of not less than one calendar month. TO THE COMPANY'S BANKERS: - in LONDON,—BAROLAY COMPANY, Limited, 64, Lombard Street, E.O. In EGYPT,-ANQLO-EQYPTIAN BANK, Limited. 5 Share Warrants to Bearer will be issued when required. Shares maybe paid up in full on or any time within two months from allotment.
Directors

DIRECTORS. SIR WILLIAM F. HAYNES 8MITH, K C.M.G., LLD., Isis High CommissioBtir-of'' Cypres (1898-1904), 8, Bentinok Street, Manchester Square, W., Chairman. MAJOR CHARLES HYDE VILLIER3, 1, Great Cumberland Plaoe, W. ARTHUR PASTON MACK, Managing Director Nile Valley Company, Limited, ‘ * Palmerston Home, E.C. ■ FREDERICK RUSSELL ROBERTS, no occupation, Little Wood, 8unningdale, Berks. JAMES WOODROW MATTHEWS, Merchant, of Matthews,' Wrightson & Co., 65 Sl 56, Bishopsgate Street Within, and Lloyds, E.C. DIRECTORS IN EGYPT. AYERST HENHAM HOOKER, F.LC, F.C.S. Boulak, Caito. HIS EXCELLENCY CROOKBHANK PASHA, British Commissioner of the Dafra Sanieh Compauy, Limited, Cairo. NIKOLAUS LONSDORFBR, Merchant, Cairo.
Solicitors

This Company is formed for the purpose of carrying on the business ot an Investment,Exploration^! Development Company, especially in Egypt and the 8oudan. ^ For some years private Syndicates have been exploring oonoesffons granted by the Egyptian and Soudan Governments with tery satisfactory results; districts previously unexplored have been opened up, aud laud hitherto of little value is now steadily improving in price, and is in great demand. The irrigation and reclamation schemes projected are likely to still farther increase the investment demand for laud In view of the above, it ia proposed that this Company shall pay epeoial attention to business connected with land development irrigation schemes, aud reclamation works. It is generally admitted that the many industries of Egypt, unler the careful supervision of the Government, are now malting stead, progress. It is - intended to act as financial- agents in JJoodoi^ Fans and elsewhere for laud development, mining and other oompanies, and i. is anticipated that considerable profit will result from this source. In view of the increasing interest of Freooh Investors in Bgyptian Securities, it is proposed to open a Branch Offise ia Paris at a.: early date. As the suooess of Company of this nature is to a large extent dependent upon a thorough knowledge of looal conditions, it is extrem ely satisfactory to have secured the servioes, as Director and Agent-General in Egypt, of Mr. Hooker, late Geueral Manager of the Bgyptian Salt and Soda Company, formerly Direotor-Ueneral of the Egyptian Government Salt Department in Egypt ;his knowledge of the oonatry and local business conditions is probably unequalled. Mr. Hooker has consented to act tor a period of three years, at a salary of £1,000 per anuum, with a farther remuneration equal to 5 per cent, of the net profits in eaoh year available for distribution among the shareholders ^whether distributed or not) in excess of an amount equal to £10 per cent, on the capital paid up on the Sharee of the Company for the time being issued. 100,000 shares forming part of the present issue have been underwritten at a commission of 3 per cent, with an over-riding commission of 1 per oent which will be paid by the Company. 'Hie Directors are interested as sub-underwriters, and each will receive the 4 per oent on the number of shares underwritten by him as follows: — Sir William F. Haynes Smith, 2,000 Shares; Major Villiers, 10,000 Shares; AIL Hooker, 5,000 Shares; F. Russell Roberta, 5,000 Shares; J.W. Matthews, 6,000 Shares j H.E. Crookshank Facha, 500 Shares. The preliminary expenses, including registration lees and stamp duty, legal expenses aud brokers' fees, the ooet of advertising aud issuing this Froepectus, down to and including the allotment other than the underwriting commission and brokerage, are estimated s £4,000, which will be paid by the Company. No promotion money has been or will be paid. The Company will pay a brokerage of 8d- per shares to Bankers on all shares applied for and allotted to the publio on forms bearing the Banker's and Broker's stamp. Applications tor shares can only be made on the form accompanying the prospectus which ooc tains the particulars required by law. Frospeouisea and Application Forms can be obtained at the Uttioes at the Company, the Bankers, Broken and Solicitors, or from the Secretaries, and wiU be sent on reoeipt of a telegram addressed "Hooker Cairo." j This advertisement it not intended as an mntaqon to subscribe.

div.head: Equal Good For the lungs and the stomach
div.p: It has been truly said that “ Nothing goes right while the stomach is ' wrong.” 5 It is therefore important in treating lung troubles to keep the digestive organs in a healthy condition. That is just what Angler’s Emulsion does; it promoted appetite, aids diges- tion and improves nutrition, while at the same time it soothes and heals the lungs and air passages. It is this combined effect upon the respiratory and digestive’organs that makes it superior to any other remedy for lung affections and wasting diseases.

div.head: Mesopotamia
div.p: The Mesopotamia treated in this report is the true delta of the rivers Euphrates and Tigris, and comprises the country traversed by the two rivers and thieir branches southwards of Hit on the Euphrates and Beled near the site of the ancient Opis on.the Tigris. From Hit to Gama, past the ancient Babylon, is the Euphrates. The Hindia Canal is the branch which leaves the Euphrates hear Mosaib and joins it again at Sawama, after flowing through -the Sea of Nejef. From Beled to Gama, past Bagdad and Am.ara, is the Tigris. The Hai Canal leaves the Tigris at Root and flows into, the Euphrates near Sheikh es Shayak. During the Khalifate this canal was the main channel of the Tigris. From Gurna,' the junction of the two rivers, to Fao on the Persian Gulf, the joint stream is called the Basra River. By the Arabs it is known as the Shaat el Arab, or the River of the Arabs. in. THE EUPHRATES. The Euphrates enters its delta at Hit, where there are excellent limestone quarries and bitumen springs. From Hit to the Persian Gulf, on a length of some 930 kilometres, the river rolls its yellow water through an open, plain, bounded on the west by the desert. Uu the east pr left bank, islands of the gravelly desert are met with south of Feluja and again near Mosaib. - , Ffom Hit to Feluja, on a length of about 130 kilometres, the river is broad,, varying m width from 250 to 450 metres, the current is about 3 kilometres an hour, aud the average . depth 3.50 mptres. The valley is narrow, liable to overflow in places in high floods, and irriga- tion is in great part carried on by “charads” where water is raised in bullock skms by means of a rope passed over' a pulley ami drawn np by mules or horses going down and up an incline. . From Feluja to Mosaib, a distance of some 90 kilometres, the average width of the river is 250 metres. The trough of the Euphrates is some 3 metres deep down to the level ot low supply, and a flood of 3.50 metres puts the country under half a metre of water, against which it is protected by dykes, which are not very effective, and are occasionally burst, causing serious inundations. The following table of mean heights of the Euphrates at Mosaib will give a good idea oi the times of flood and low supply of the river. The figures are very approximati ve but they represent the best information obtained by me.

div.head: YOU MAY HAVE IT AND NOT KNOW
div.p: The kidneys are intended by nature to drain off the surplus water and the body’s impurities You know how well and strong and robust yen feel when the kidneys are working right. You feel right in every way. But how do you feel when the kidneys become clogged and diseased 1. * Tired,, miserable, sleepless, nervous, rest- less, back lame, and acbjng and' weak—can’t stoop, Can’t staud without pain ; rheumatic, gouty, dizzy, ^eak; no appbtite, etc. These- symptoms and a thousand others come from tbe impurities in the blood, which sick kidneys have not taken out of the body. Doan'8 backache kidney pills tone and he»l the kidneys, and enable them to take all them disease poisons out of the system. The medi- cine’s effect is quick and sure; it dees not act on the bowels, only on the kidneys and bladder. The pills do one thing, and do it well. Doan’8 backache kidney pills are for sa'e xby all chemists and druggists for P.T. 18 pe' box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may bt Jiad by post from the general agent for Egypt Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil-street, Mousky, Cairo.

div.head: Al Azhar University
div.p: The following articles translated from “A1 Chark” give a fair, idea of one side of native opinion in reference to the A1 Azhar crisis : — “We refrained from reproducing the rumours published by our contemporaries in Cairo with regard to A1 Azhar until the storm had passed and the agitation was brought, to silence, and until our colleagues had saved themselves the trouble of disoussions and explanations. Now that tranquillity has beeu restored and the weather has resumed its former calmness, and the reser- vists of A1 Azhar have been allowed a free hand,- we may asktba reformers these questions: What will A1 Azhar become hereafter 1 and what will be the condition of its graduates once they have acquired the religious sciences taught in it ? Will it be more than a religious college wherein nothing but the Mohamedau law is taught, and the sheikhs, on being graduated, will they be acquainted with anythihg else besides religious questions ? Where will this great army get their daily bread once they have left A1 Azhar and become Ulema in reli- gion and' Imams of the believers I There is no monastery in Mohamedanism so that they might abandon this world,put on haircloth and live away in seclusion ; on the contrary, they will have to marry and increase in number, and this involves energy and skill to obtain the necessary means of sustenance'. Bat how can such persons take part in the dreadful battle of life unprepared for it and devoid of any social knowledge 1 Will the Hakkanieh (Ministry of Justice) find sufficient employment for all of them as jndges, bashkatibs, and muftis 1 This question deserves much medita- tion. The Grand Mufti of Egypt, Sheikh Mo hamed Abdou, as well as Sheikh Abdilkarim Silmajo, have both resigued their poits in the Council of Administration at Al Azhar owing to the objection of the majority of the sheikhs there to include any worldly (modern) science in the curriculum and insisting on confining themselves to religious studies exclusively.” “In our issue of yesterday we expressed an opinion regarding A1 Azhar and said we won- dered whether thfese Ulema, with no experience of anything except religious matters, would be able to earn their living. A Moslem friend has just sent us the following communication in response to our questions : You have asked an important question with freedom aud courage at a time when other papers have passed over the terrible weakness in the re- gulations of the greatest Mohamedan uni- versity. Endless discussions are now going on in this connection, and a great number of our .earned sheikhs are complimenting each other on their escape from tne board of examinations, and are thanking God that they will no more become mathematicians, geographers, natural- ists, or chemists. This greatest ot universities contains ten thousand students ; each one ot them is strong enough to remove a mountain ; Alexander, Haunibal, and Bonaparte, who covered the world' with fire and blood, had not stouter bodies nor stronger arms ; neither were ihe students at Paris greater in number when in 1892 a prime minister apologised to them and excused himself. I had occasion to see a party of students at A1 Azhar whom I suppos- ed to be moving rocks and speaking mountains. I noticed one of them had a dispute with another on a certain matter of opinion, and a nig fight ensned : boxing, and biting were indulged in freely, and the earth trembleu with cries. On another occasion I heard some sheikhs speaking there ; so sweet were, their words, so plehsaut tneir conversation, so clear tlieir: minds, and so excellent their- charac- tera«-as to surpass all expectations. I heard one of them discuss a religious i .question with such competence and modesty aud con- vincing proofs as I have , never before seen or heard. This numerous army of human oeings should be the source of Arabic literature and the most reliable body on both worldly and religious science. It should be the equip- ments and weapons to Islamism, its peace,and its war. This force should be converted into virtnonsness ; this youthliilness into righteous- ness ; this intelligence and ability into fortresses and fortifications. A1 Azhar should be the centre of all hopes, and the object of the greatest care and attention. If.it become ill it should be doctored, and if it become crooked it shonld be put straight. But if all means have failed and there is no hope of recovery it is then right that it? should be thrown down stone by stone and demolished to the ground. “Have you ever seen a young sheikh in hi» first year at Al Azhar 1 It he preached in >■ village abd said to the inhabitants, ‘ God com- mands you not to sell your cotton,’ do you i-hink any one of them would dare to sell one pound of cotton 1 And if he were to say that Ghina was a town at a short distance from Ghirgeh, and that it was rushing upon them to deprive them of their properties; would there be any one without a naboot, a rifle, or an axe, and would you hear anything but screams and cries 1 If plagiie, cholera, or fever prevailed in an epidemic form and this y.iung sheikh of Al Azhar came and said, ‘ 0 people, there is no contagion in Islamism, al is due to destiny,’would the Sanitary Adml nistration find any one to hearken to its idvice or follow its precautions ? Such is tb> fluence of these sheikhs upon the puhlii uinda that it is absolutely necessary that they should he intelligent and well-instructed. Al Azhar contains two distinct parties : the one composed of those who go. to study and learn, and tbe other of those who oonsider Al Azhai asylum ora place of retuge for those wli'i scape from military service or are tire' >f judicial supervision, or are sick of thi world and its disappointments. The former ac in accordance with the ‘ Holy Hadith ’ : Seel knowledge though in China ; the latter atten- i t Al .Azhar not with the intention to study but merely on woount of itn being a ' Tikia ’ wherein the greatest desire is to be left quiet in their beds, and be served with their daily food regularly. “This is the real cause of what is at present called disorder and trouble at Al Azhar, and which in reality is but a noble struggle for the better. Now that the reformers have relin- quished their posts iu the administration of that uuiversity, and that the reactionary party has gained a complete victory over the pro- gressive party, the only answer to yonr ques- tion is that the numerous body of students have completely detached themselves from public society so that they do not understand the public nor do the public understand them; they aot in a way which the public will not fol- low. When this great army finds itself without -work and without sustenance, it will spread itself among the people and infect their minds with every species of ignorance. It will ingra- tiate itself amoDg'the public by means of mi- racles and wonders, and will exert influence on their admirers with canning sorcery and magio to deprive them even of their clothingi The country will encounter enormous difficulties through this army. No cultivation will be com- pleted, no cotton will be sold, no precautions will be taken against epidemic diseases, no modem project of the oivilised world will be considered until the learned adviser has been consulted. It will not be unusual tosee acommonmanarguing firmly that the sun sets in the sea, and that there is a special moon for each month, and that no man should seek his bread but that the bread follows the man wherever he goes, and so on. I pray the gracious God that He may not reduce Al Azhar to such a state, and that that institution may be restored to its ancient position in the Moslem world, and that its members may become a strong army of pro- gress and usefulness.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Conseil d’Administration de la SocidW Anonyme des Eaux du Cairo a l’honneur d’in- former Messieurs les porteurs d’actions et parts de fondateur de la dite Socifitd : I. — Q.u’eu execution des deliberations de rAssembiee Generate Extraordinaire du 9 Mars 1905, il tient a leur disposition 36240 actions liberees de la Compagnie Frigorifique d’Egypte, d’une valeur nomi- nate de 4 L.E. chacune, leur revenant com me prix de la vente de la glaci£re h cette Compagnie, A raison de : 1 action de la Compagnie Frigorifique pour deux actions de la Societe des Eaux (ordinaires ou de jouissance). 2 actions de la Compagnie Frigorifique pour trois parts de fondateur de la Societe des Eaux. II. — Qu’en outre, la Societe des Eaux du Cairo est chargee par le Conseil d’Admi- nistration de la Compagnie Frigorifique d’Egypte, d’offrir eft souscription aux por- teurs d’actions et de Parts de fondateur de la Societe des Eaux du Cairo, 7,136 ac- tions au porteur de la Compagnie Frig.m- fique d’Egypte, an pair, c’est-A-dire an prix de 4 L.E. chacune, enticement payable en . souscrivant, A raison de one action de la Compagnie Frigorifiqtie pour 10 actions (ordinaires on de jouissance) ou pour 10 parts de fondatenT de la Societe des Eanx du Caire. Tontes les actions de la Compagnie Frigorifique mentionnees ci-dessus, jouis- sent des memos droits et participant aux benefices du ler exercice. Les porteurs d’actions ordinaires ou‘ de jouissance et de parts de fondateur de la Sooiete Anonyme des Eaux du Cairo, sont en consequence invites : a) A presenter, A partir du 15 Avril 1905, au si6ge de la Societe des Eaux du Cairo, et aveo bordereaux numeriques par eux signes, leurs titres d’actions ordinaires on de jouissance et de parts de fondatenrs pour recevoir les actions de la Compagnie Frigorifiqne leur revenant comma indique snb I ci-dessus. b) A exercer lenr droit de sonsoription snr les 7136 notions de la Compagnie Frigori- fique mentionnees sub II ci-dessus, A par- tir du 15 Avril 1905 et jusqu’au 5 Mai 1905 inolusivement, au plus tard, au siege de la Sooiete des Eaux du Cairo, oh il sera tenu A leur disposition des formulas sur lesqueUes ils auront A indiquer les numeros de leurs titres des Eaux du Caire. Les souscriptions devront 6tre accompa- gnees: . ‘ 1. du versement A la Caisse de la Sooiete des Eaux, du montant des actions sous- crites. 2. de la presentation des titres de la Sooiete des Eaux pour 6tre estampilies. Aucune souscription ne sera re$ue aprfes la date sue indiquee du 5 Mai 1905.
